issues.title: reference to "conflict of interest"
issues.author: richsalz
issues.body:
The original doc says in the first paragraph of section 3:
```
WG participants should specifically note the
requirements for disclosure of conflicts of interest in [2].
```

[2] is RFC 2028, obsoleted by 9281 and neither one of these mentions conflict of interest.

See email thread at https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/ietf/8mEwZkwtL-WNCPyZ5hBd7FaWVq8/

comments.author: richsalz
comments.body: Per email with Scott, this should probably be a reference to 2026 because that talks about disclosures.

From Brian E Carpenter on the mailing list:

> Adoption is _not_ a formal step in the IETF process described by RFC 2026

issues.title: do virtual side meetings count as BOFs
issues.author: mcr
issues.body:
I think some clarification would be useful as to whether virtual interim (side)meetings count as BOFs.

2418 speaks about 1 BOF, with 2 being an exception.
2 BOFs is now very common, with one or more side meetings even occuring.
BOF organizers/proponents often (particularly pandemic) have weekly to monthly organizing meetings.
This is done using ad-hoc meeting technology, which often results in problems accessing for some, lack of good records.  Many would prefer to use meetecho for this, but then there was push back that said if it used the official tool, then it would be a BOF.
If the reason to limit BOFs to <= 2 is due to time constraints for plenary week, then any time elsewhere (elsewhen?) should not count.
If there are other reasons to limit BOF, then they should be enumerated.

There is also now an IAB involvement in bringing new work.

replacing ietf-wg-procon/2026bis#19, and this issue should move to other repo.

comments.author: DavidSchinazi
comments.body:
Personal comment from Jari Arkko [on the list](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/procon/FHxd8FXHbETUaEFT3HxVf0gXjeQ/):

> Just an observation that this is a reality-alignment beyond the specific cases mentioned in our charter. That’s ok, but let’s remember that. I think we’ve also slipped on the strictness of the hard BoF number limits. Maybe that's fair because typically the topic shifts during the discussion so BoF # 2 for instance may be quite different from BoF # 1. One option could be to soften the rule instead of starting to specify the application of the rule to the virtual case.

comments.author: mcr
comments.body:
BOF#2 was supposed to be a rare event in 2418.
It's anything but.  We established this rule because plenary time was
expensive, and we didn't have easy virtual meetings.  (It's even *MORE*
expensive now in my opinion)

In-person BOF sessions at the plenary are at the discretion of ADs/IESG, and so let's
just let them decide.
In most cases, the virtual meetings are used to prepare.
I'd prefer to be able to use meetecho for that; because recordings and NoteWell.
This has been denied because it would "count", and I'd rather we just didn't.

comments.author: DavidSchinazi
comments.body: This was discussed in the PROCON meeting at IETF 124. Sense of the room was to remove the text saying that BoFs have to happen at plenary meetings. We would keep the two BoF limit and that would extend to all kinds of BoFs (in-person plenary, in-person out of cycle, virtual out of cycle, working-group forming, non-working group forming, etc). If we want to change the limit, that would be a specific issue - and might not be in charter.

issues.title: Do we need to remove draft standard from 2418 text?
issues.author: jariarkko
issues.body:
You’ve recently changed 2026bis to be clear what the current standard levels are while also noting that the draft standard level is still out there for some documents. That’s great, thank you. 

Here’s the text you currently have:

Specifications that are intended to become Internet Standards evolve through a set of maturity levels known as the "standards track". These maturity levels -- "Proposed Standard" and "Internet Standard" -- are defined and discussed in Section 6.1. The way in which specifications move along the standards track is described in Section 8.

There used to be a status that came between Proposed Standard and Internet Standard called "Draft Standard." As of the writing of this document, there still exist some RFCs at that status. Documents at Draft Standard may be advanced to Internet Standard, either via the procedure described in Section 8 (if they meet the requirements of Section 6.1.1) or with the consent of the IESG. The IESG may also decide to remove the Draft Standard status from a document and mark it as either Historic or Proposed Standard.

But it seems to me that the following texts in 2418bis are also something that should be impacted:

5. Working Group Termination

Working groups are typically chartered to accomplish a specific task or tasks. After the tasks are complete, the group will be disbanded. However, if a WG produces a Proposed or Draft Standard, the WG will frequently become dormant rather than disband (i.e., the WG will no longer conduct formal activities, but the mailing list will remain available to review the work as it moves to Draft Standard and Standard status.)

…

7.1. WG Chair

...

Document implementations

Under the procedures described in [_2026bis], the Chair is responsible for documenting the specific implementations which qualify the specification for Draft or Internet Standard status along with documentation about testing of the interoperation of these implementations.

Or am I missing something?

pulls.title: Make milestones optional
pulls.author: DavidSchinazi
pulls.body: This PR incorporates draft-schinazi-update-on-milestones into draft-ietf-procon-2418bis. It makes changes to all mentions of milestones in the document.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: It seems very restrictive that the decision whether or not to specify milestones is made once and for all when a WG is first chartered. It would be quite plausible for a WG with or without milestones to change mode as its role evolves. I suggest that it should be "when a WG is first chartered _or rechartered_".

comments.author: DavidSchinazi
comments.body:
Hi @becarpenter, I agree with you. This is already the case though - does the following sentence not cover it for you?

> Similarly, the Area Director can enable or disable milestones, or enable or disable dates, or change the granularity of dates, all without a formal recharter.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: Yes, I guess, but the present text could be read as setting the decision in concrete.

comments.author: DavidSchinazi
comments.body: That's totally fair, and I'm happy to improve it. Do you have a suggestion for how to make it sound less final without repeating the other section too much?

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
You know, one word would do it:

> While chartering a new working group, the IESG will decide whether
> milestones are _initially_  enabled or disabled for this working group,

comments.author: DavidSchinazi
comments.body: I like that. Added the word "initially". Thanks for the suggestion.

Presumably, this could be **changed** by mutual agreement of AD+chairs.
That the choice does not require a charter revision. You say that later on.  
And that it does not require the tooling to enforce the choice?
It seems like a lot words here.

This requires tooling changes.
(I think that milestones would get used and update more often if WG chairs could do this without supervision)
It does. But we intentionally don't go into the details of the tooling in this document. Just state what is possible and let the IESG work with the tools team to figure out the details
Yes, it can be changed later. We say that though. I don't think we should get into the details of tooling in this document.

> It does. But we intentionally don't go into the details of the tooling in this document. Just state what is possible and let the IESG work with the tools team to figure out the details

I'm not concerned about the tooling requirement, but the detail of who has authority to do what does need to feed into the tooling.

> Yes, it can be changed later. We say that though. I don't think we should get into the details of tooling in this document.

I'm not seeing text that says that here.

```suggestion
While chartering a new working group, the IESG will decide whether
milestones are enabled or disabled for this working group, and if enabled whether there are dates included, and at what granularity.
The responsible Area Director is empowered to change these details without formal updates to the charter.
The Area Director is encouraged to discuss these choices with the working group chairs, as the
success of milestones is predicated on the chairs updating them in a timely manner. 
Updating the date attached to a milestone is under the authority of the working group chairs and does not require pre-approval of the Area Director.  
However, in the case of a disagreement the final decision lies with the Area Director.
```

Is any IESG decision unchangeable? But I agree that it is probably worth making explicit here. Perhaps something like at the end: "This decision can be revisited at any time, when requested by the IESG, the AD, or the WG Chairs."
